prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for asking my sister to cover her self harm scars
Ok so I know how this sounds but I have to know because it’s really getting to me.

So my sister is four years older than me and right now she is living at home having just left University and is looking for a job. When my sister was seventeen she was bullied really badly and due to this she would self harm for a really long time. I don’t know how my parents didn’t notice it but when they did they took her to therapy and eventually it stopped. She’s come a really long way since then and I’m so proud of her but she still has scars on her arms that are clearly noticeable. I’ve never been depressed or self harmed so I’m not in the right position to tell her what to do and I can’t even begin to imagine her point of view.

However around the house she always leaves her arms bare and most of the time it’s fine but it really really upsets me sometimes to see them because it makes me so angry that someone could have bullied her to the point that she did that. I know I’m being selfish by saying that because it’s not about me but it’s beginning to affect our relationship as whenever I’m around her now I just feel so sad. I casually mentioned that I could see the scars the other day when we were alone and she got really upset and started crying. I instantly felt horrible and I wish I had never said anything. I don’t know how to fix this and I need to know if I’m being unreasonable.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the sister has self-harm scars from when she was bullied, and the author, who's younger, feels upset seeing them. The author mentioned it once, and the sister got upset. Now the author is wondering if they're at fault.

First, I need to consider the dynamics. The sister is four years older and has been through a lot. The author mentions they've never experienced depression or self-harm, so they might not fully understand the sister's perspective. The author's intention was to ask the sister to cover the scars, but doing so made the sister cry. That's a strong reaction.

The key points here might be about boundaries and empathy. The author is trying to express their feelings, but maybe didn't realize how sensitive the topic is. The sister might feel that the author is judging her or bringing up past trauma unnecessarily. Even though the author's intention was to avoid feeling sad, the sister might feel invalidated or reminded of her pain.

Also, the author acknowledges they might be being selfish. The sister's scars are a part of her history, and she might have worked hard to recover. The author's comment could have triggered her, especially if she's still healing. Even if the author meant to be supportive, bringing up the scars without the sister being comfortable could be seen as invasive.

On the other hand, the author is struggling with their own emotions and wants to protect their mental state. They might feel that seeing the scars makes them sad because of the bullying their sister endured. But the sister has the right to decide what she's comfortable with regarding her body and privacy.

The main issue is whether the author overstepped by bringing it up. The sister's emotional reaction suggests that the author did. The author might not have considered that the sister might not want to discuss or hide her scars, and that the act of mentioning it was hurtful, regardless of the author's intention. So the author probably is in the wrong here because they didn't respect the sister's boundaries and possibly reopened old wounds.
